courses.subject: SPED
courses.title: Introduction to Human Movement Science
courses.description: This course provides an overview of the fundamental concepts, principles, and applications of human movement science. Students will explore the anatomical, physiological, biomechanical, and neurological mechanisms that underlie human movement and physical activity. Through a combination of lectures, labs, and hands-on activities, students will develop a strong foundational understanding of the science of human movement. This introductory course lays the groundwork for a more advanced study in the multidisciplinary field of human movement science, such as exercise physiology, biomechanics, athletic training, and exercise psychology.
courses.component:
Classwork
Discussion
Exercise
Laboratory
Lecture
Project
courses.academic_group: Dept of Sports Sc & Phy Edu
courses.academic_org: Dept of Sports Sc & Phy Edu
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students will be able to:
• explain the anatomical and physiological basis of human movement
• analyze the biomechanical principles governing human motion
• describe the neural mechanisms underlying motor control and learning
• evaluate factors that influence physical activity and exercise
• apply human movement science concepts to promote health, fitness, and human performance
courses.course_syllabus:
Key topics covered in the course include:

* Introduction to Human Movement Science
* Anatomical Foundations of Human Movement
* Physiological Mechanisms of Human Movement
* Biomechanics of human motion, including kinematics and kinetics
* Motor control and motor learning theories
* Adaptation to training
* Analysis
* Principles of physical activity, exercise, and fitness
* Applications of Human Movement Science
courses.feedback_evaluation: Feedback from students will be collected through email exchanges and course-end evaluation.
courses.required_readings: Potteiger, J. A. (2023). ACSM's Introduction to Exercise Science (4th ed.). Wolters Kluwer
courses.recommended_readings:
• Kenney, W. L. (2015). Physiology of sport and exercise (6th ed.). Champaign, IL: Human Kinetics.
• McGinnis, P. M. (2013). Biomechanics of sport and exercise (3rd ed.). Champaign, IL: Human Kinetics.
• Marieb, E. N., & Keller, S. M. (2017). Essentials of human anatomy and physiology (12th ed.). Pearson.

courses.subject: SPED
courses.title: Racquet Sports
courses.description: This course is designed to introduce students to racquet sports such as table tennis, badminton, tennis and/or squash. The fundamental knowledge, skills, rules and strategies will be covered for each racquet sport selected. The course is conducted from the point of view of applied sport science and usually involves solving complex movement problems such as the analysis of the movement skills for sports performance. With the application of generic skills such as communication, collaboration, critical thinking and problem solving skills, students are encouraged to develop self-learning skills and design innovative training strategies to strengthen their competence and confidence in racquet sports, so as to be able them for promoting racquet sports in primary and secondary schools or other community sport setting. The values and standards in racquet sports are addressed to nurture students to be professional educators or sports personnel in their future careers.

courses.description: This course will train students to acquire the skills to become competent physical educators and coaches teaching and/or coaching fundamental movement and dance skills. Key elements such as observational skill, motor learning ability as well as other vital teaching techniques will be emphasized in this course. Students will be assessed by three domains including: (a) knowledge, (b) skill performance, and (c) skill demonstration. In the section of fundamental movement skills (FMS), students are required to innovate and organize different modes of teaching strategies and learning activities for teaching locomotor, stability and manipulative skills. In dance section, students work in group to design the choreography for dance. This course will also develop students' generic skills such as the creativity, communication, collaboration and problem solving skills through the learning activities of fundamental movement skills and dance, so as to enable them to teach confidently and professionally in their future careers.

courses.subject: SPED
courses.title: Exercise Nutrition and Health
courses.description: This course will provide an overview and in-depth knowledge in Exercise, Nutrition & Health, so as to optimize students’ understanding in a range of core concepts related to physical activity, general heath and performance. With the content based on recent published scientific research, this course will explore how nutritional composition impacts on the regulation of health status, exercise performance and training outcomes. It is suitable for any student wishing to pursue a career in sport medicine, exercise training, coaching, physical education and within the professional sports industry.
courses.academic_group: Dept of Sports Sc & Phy Edu
courses.academic_org: Dept of Sports Sc & Phy Edu
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students should be able to:

1. Demonstrate knowledge and understanding of the human responses to exercise, nutritional intake and their effect on health and performance.
2. Apply knowledge and understanding of the interrelated roles of nutrition and physical activity and their roles in the prevention and treatment of metabolic health.
3. Utilise transferable skills to accurately assess nutritional intake, exercise output, body composition and markers of clinical health.
4. Administer relevant knowledge to design an evidence based individual nutritional and exercise plan to achieve various health & performance outcomes.
5. Exhibit the ability to collaborate effectively with peers in the production of scientific reports and performing oral presentations.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1: Introduction to human nutrition and exercise performance.
Week 2: Dietary assessment methods and macronutrients. Week 3: Micronutrients; Nutrition and chronic disease.
Week 4: Nutrition strategies and body composition.
Week 5: Energy balance, appetite
Regulation and managing at-risk athletes
Week 6: Nutrition before, during and after sports performance.
Week 7: Efficacy and risk of supplements and ergogenic aids for health and performance.
Week 8: Nutrition across the lifecycle, in special populations and environmental conditions
Week 9: Energy requirements for health and exercise.
Week 10: Fluid nutrition, ion balance and thermoregulation.
Week 11: Nutritional intake, physical activity and chronic disease management
Week 12: Revision and summary
Week 13: In-class group presentations
courses.feedback_evaluation: Email exchanges and course-end evaluation
courses.required_readings: Sport and Exercise Nutrition (5th edition). McArdle WD, Katch FI and Katch VL (eds). Lippincott Williams and Wilkins
courses.recommended_readings: To be provided by course teacher

courses.description: This course aims to develop students’ knowledge of the structure and function of human body in relation to physical education and exercise science. A number of the body’s systems will be examined with an emphasis being placed on the musculoskeletal system. Common musculoskeletal injuries experienced during physical activity and exercise will also be discussed. Apart from lectures, laboratories and tutorials will be utilized to develop and reinforce student learning.

courses.academic_org: Dept of Sports Sc & Phy Edu
courses.learning_outcomes:
The objectives of this course are as follows:
• To develop knowledge of the structure and function of the body’s systems involved in human movement.
• To develop the ability to describe and critically analyze joint movement and muscle function in human movement.

courses.subject: SPED
courses.title: Introduction to Exercise Physiology
courses.description:
The human body is an amazingly complex machine. All of its various cells and tissues communicate with each other, and their activities are precisely coordinated. In order to understand how the body performs and responds to physical activity, it is important to build a foundation of knowledge in the field of sport and exercise physiology. Therefore, the general aim of this course is to provide the students with up-to-date information for understanding the physiology of exercise.

This course examines the basic concepts of energy metabolism, nutrition and the physiological responses to exercise and training. Emphasis will be placed on the application of such knowledge upon teaching physical education and upon the improvement of exercise performance. The students are provided with hands-on experience of conducting laboratory work, which examines the physical responses to exercise.
courses.academic_group: Dept of Sports Sc & Phy Edu
courses.academic_org: Dept of Sports Sc & Phy Edu
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students will be able to:

• explain the metabolic responses involved in bioenergetics.

• describe the nutrients that are used as fuels during exercise.

• discuss the relationship between exercise intensity/duration and the physiological responses involved.

• understand the influence of nutrition on human performance.

• demonstrate the basic laboratory techniques on exercise testing.
courses.course_syllabus:
• Introduction to exercise and sport physiology

• Muscular control of movement

• Neuromuscular adaptations to resistance training

• Causes of fatigue (lab demonstration)

• Basic energy systems

• Hormonal regulation of exercise

• Neuromuscular and metabolic adaptations to training

• Cardiorespiratory function and adaptations to training

• Thermal regulation and exercise

• Nutrition and exercise performance

• Lab practical class

• Exercise in hypobaric, hyperbaric environment

• Ergogenic aids and exercise performance
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are welcome to express feedback on course contents and learning experience via e-mail to the course instructors anytime during the course. A standardized course evaluation form will be provided at the end of the course for students to provide feedback.
courses.required_readings: Wilmore, J. H., Costill, D. L., and Kenny, W. L. (2015) Physiology of sport and exercise (6th Edition) Champaign, IL : Human Kinetics.

courses.subject: SPED
courses.title: Basic Statistics, Test and Measurement for Physical Education
courses.description: This course will help the student to develop an introductory level of statistical competence and computing for a general understanding of the contribution of measurement and data analysis techniques used in Sports Science and Physical Education. Students are expected to practice lab skills inside and outside class time. E-learning platform using flipped classroom and blackboard are mandatory.
courses.academic_group: Dept of Sports Sc & Phy Edu
courses.academic_org: Dept of Sports Sc & Phy Edu
courses.course_syllabus:
• Measurement:
 -Principles of Measurement and Evaluation.
 -Selection of the measuring instrument, scientific authenticity.
 -Validity, reliability and objectivity, administrative feasibility, educational application.
 -Norm and criterion referenced measurement.
 -Measurement of Physical Ability
 -Measurement of Physical Fitness
 -Measurement of Cognitive Domain in Sports & PE
 -Measurement of Affective Domain in Sports & PE
• Statistics:
 -Measurement concepts: meaning and limitations, statistics, sources of data.
 -Descriptive and inferential statistics; scales of measurement - nominal, ordinal, discrete etc.
 -Organizing and presenting data: Measures of typical achievement, central tendency, mean, median and mode, normal distribution.
 -Measures of variation: range; standard deviation; variation; coefficient of variation.
 -Measures of relationships: scatter diagrams, concepts of correlation.
 -Assumptions of various statistics models.
 -Parametric and non-parametric statistics; Within-subject and Between-subject designs.
 -Inferential statistics: standard error, t-distribution, degree of freedom, differences between means, null hypothesis, correlated and uncorrelated data, t-tests, regression and ANOVA.
 -Statistical significance, one-tailed and two-tailed tests, levels of significance.
• Computing:
 -Basic components of a microcomputer, variables input and output, searching, sorting. Spreadsheets, data processing, application of statistical software (SPSS) and graphic software.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are welcome to express feedback on course contents and learning experience via e-mail to the course instructor anytime during the course. A standardized course evaluation form will be provided at the end of the course for students to provide feedback.

courses.subject: SPED
courses.title: Introduction to Exercise Biomechanics
courses.description: This course introduces students to the important biomechanical principles that relate to human movement. Applications to teaching and coaching are provided in this course in the form of fundamental movement patterns and sports-specific techniques. Furthermore, concepts related to injury prevention are discussed. In addition to lectures, students will participate in practical sessions to facilitate their learning.
courses.academic_group: Dept of Sports Sc & Phy Edu
courses.academic_org: Dept of Sports Sc & Phy Edu
courses.course_syllabus:
• Understand the basic biomechanical principles of human movement

• Compute the kinematics of movements undergoing linear motion

• Compute the kinematics of movements undergoing angular motion

• Understand projectile motion

• Describe and apply Newton’s law of motion

• Explain kinetic concepts of friction, momentum, impulse and impact

• Describe the factors that affect mechanical stability

• Levers and segment sequencing (throw-like and push-like patterns)

• Explain the concepts of drag, lift, and spin

• Practically apply biomechanical principles in qualitative analysis

courses.subject: SPED
courses.title: Principles of Strength Training and Conditioning
courses.description: This course involves an in-depth exploration of the fundamental theories and practices behind effective strength and conditioning programming. It covers the physiological adaptations to resistance training, including muscular, neural, and metabolic changes. Students will learn how to properly assess an individual's fitness level and needs, and then design comprehensive training programmes to improve strength, power, speed, agility, and endurance.
courses.academic_group: Dept of Sports Sc & Phy Edu
courses.academic_org: Dept of Sports Sc & Phy Edu
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students should be able to:
- Understand the fundamental physiology of skeletal muscle and the adaptations that occur with resistance training
- Analyze the neurological, metabolic, and cardiovascular adaptations to different strength and conditioning modalities
- Assess an individual's current fitness level, goals, and training needs through appropriate performance testing
- Design periodized, sport-specific strength and conditioning programs to improve muscular strength, power, speed, agility, and endurance
- Demonstrate proficiency in teaching and coaching proper exercise technique for a variety of resistance training movements
- Identify common strength training injuries and implement appropriate preventative and rehabilitative strategies
- Evaluate the role of nutrition, supplementation, and recovery in supporting training adaptations
- Apply evidence-based principles of program design to create effective training plans for diverse populations
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1: Introduction to Strength Training and Conditioning
- Overview of course objectives, topics, and assessments
- Importance of strength and conditioning for health, fitness, and athletic performance

Week 2: Muscular Anatomy and Physiology
- Structure and function of skeletal muscle
- Mechanisms of muscular contraction and force production

Week 3: Neuromuscular Adaptations to Resistance Training
- Neural factors influencing strength development
- Motor unit recruitment, rate coding, and muscular coordination

Week 4: Energy Systems and Metabolic Adaptations
- Bioenergetics of resistance exercise
- Impacts of training on the ATP-PC, glycolytic, and oxidative systems

Week 5: Principles of Program Design
- Specificity, progressive overload, and individual differences
- Periodization strategies for strength, power, and hypertrophy

Week 6: Assessment and Testing Protocols
- Fitness assessments for muscular strength, power, speed, and endurance
- Interpreting assessment data to guide program design

Week 7: Resistance Training Techniques and Exercise Selection
- Proper exercise technique for major movement patterns
- Tailoring exercises to individual needs and goals

Week 8: Midterm Exam

Week 9: Injury Prevention and Rehabilitation Considerations
- Common strength training injuries and their mechanisms
- Integrating injury prevention and rehabilitation into program design

Week 10: Nutritional Strategies for Strength and Conditioning
- Macronutrient needs for muscle growth and recovery
- Supplementation to support training adaptations

Week 11: Training for Specific Populations
- Adapting programs for youth, older adults, and special populations
- Considerations for training athletes in different sports

Week 12: Practical Application and Case Studies
- Student-led program design presentations and critiques
- Troubleshooting common programming challenges

Week 13: Course Wrap-up
- Comprehensive revision of course learning outcomes
- Discussions on future trends in strength and conditioning
courses.feedback_evaluation: Feedback from students will be collected through email exchanges and course-end evaluation.

courses.description: This course will explore the current issues in school physical education and sports from a sociological perspective. The course will focus on the meaning of sport and physical activity in society and how it fits into the physical education programmes in Hong Kong schools. Because most of the students taking this course are training to be physical education teachers and sports related professionals, the course will emphasize issues that relate to the role of the physical education teacher and the challenges that are expected when they enter schools as practicing professionals.

courses.description: This course aims to provide opportunities to SSPE students practice their teaching skills through the implementation and verification of teaching theories into practice. With the supervisions and guidance of SSPE TP Supervisors, External TP Supervisors and Teaching Advisors, students can equip and prepare themselves as a competent physical education teacher in the future through the experiences acquired during teaching practice. Therefore, student-teachers would grasp this opportunity to experience and understand the real situation in teaching profession. Major students are required to take 8 units of Teaching Practice (TP). These units are spread over two years of study whereas students are placed in a variety of primary schools to implement their teaching in authentic school environment and become acquainted with the organization, administration and discipline of primary schools in Hong Kong. Students can design their physical education lessons by applying the pedagogical skills and teaching theories learnt in SPED3450 (pedagogy in primary physical education) and other practical skill courses to the authentic teaching environment.

Curriculum serves as a blueprint of education with specific educational goals and actions for teaching and learning. This course is designed to introduce students to theories and concepts in curriculum planning for primary and secondary physical education (PE). In this course, current curriculum policies and guidelines addressed by the Education Bureau and curriculum models with particular reference to physical education are addressed. In addition, stages of planning, implementation and evaluation of curriculum planning are discussed. Students are guided to develop critical thinking and reflective and problem-solving skills through class discussions and group works, so that they are able to construct their ideas on PE curriculum design with the consideration of their personal teaching philosophy and the visions and missions of the entire education and physical education.
Up-to-date issues and practices related to overseas and local PE curriculums nowadays will be discussed throughout the course to let students analyze the problems and generate possible solutions for tackling with the problems encountered in PE nowadays, for instance, limited PE time, lack of motivation and low physical activity levels in PE, students’ physical abilities, health and mental issues, etc. Through the process of identifying the problems, suggesting solutions, developing action plans and evaluation, our students as the pre-service teachers would be more self-initiated to reflect their roles as a gatekeeper for developing effective PE curriculums for Hong Kong primary and secondary school students. In the 21st century, health issues are always the controversial topic all over the world. Therefore, we expect PE professionals could create a supportive and motivational learning environment in school physical education for nurturing our young generations their interests in physical activities and lifelong exercise habits in their lifetime.
courses.academic_group: Dept of Sports Sc & Phy Edu
courses.academic_org: Dept of Sports Sc & Phy Edu
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon the completion of this course, students will be able to:

• intensify their understanding on current school PE curriculums.

• recognize the current curriculum guidelines and policies adopted by the Education Bureau.

• understand the rationales, contents and concepts of various kinds of PE curriculum models.

• consider the influential factors in different stages of curriculum planning.

• design plans for school physical education curriculum for different target populations.

• apply the knowledge, theory and skills to authentic PE situations for curriculum planning in their future career

courses.subject: SPED
courses.title: Pedagogy of Secondary Physical Education
courses.description: This course is to enable students to better understand how sport, Physical Education (PE) and Physical Activity (PA) can be individualized to meet unique needs of learners of various ages, capabilities and interest in secondary school. Through adopting activity and theory-based, problem-solving and inquiry approach, students are expected to be actively engaged in a broad spectrum of individual and collaborative tasks as well as other interactive modes of learning. This course will focus on the following topics: (1) Analysis of current issues in Hong Kong school PE, sport and PA development; (2) Application of cutting edge research findings in promoting active living and professionalism; (3) The use of a reflective approach which includes a problem-based learning (PBL) and creativity in promoting and implementing active schooling and active living; (4) Analysis of learners and learning - explain how PE and PA and Sport can be individualized to meet special and unique needs of students.

courses.subject: SPED
courses.title: Sports Injury and Exercise Rehabilitation
courses.description: This course aims to help students acquire knowledge of sports injury and exercise rehabilitation. It provides an overview on the basic principles to evaluate injuries arising from sports and exercise activities, as well as application of therapeutic exercise training on injury prevention and rehabilitation.
courses.academic_group: Dept of Sports Sc & Phy Edu
courses.academic_org: Dept of Sports Sc & Phy Edu
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, students should be able to:
1. understand the mechanism of injury and how sports injury affects human performance in different sports activities
2. recognize the principles in assessing and managing common sports injuries, return to play criteria
3. understand the recovery process and rehabilitation related to sports injuries
4. apply the principle of exercise rehabilitation
4. develop exercise programme to prevent sports injuries and rehabilitation
(Individual course teachers may update the learning outcome as and whenever necessary)
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1: Sports injury management and rehabilitation: the team approach
Week 2: Review of clinical biomechanics related to sports injuries
Week 3: Classification and diagnosis of sports injuries
Week 4: On field first aid management
Week 5: Exercise rehabilitation: training principle & prescription
Week 6: Prevention of sports injuries
Week 7: Assessing and managing upper limb sports injuries
Week 8: Assessing and managing lower limb sports injuries
Week 9: Assessing and managing spinal sports injuries
Week 10: Sports taping theory and practical application to common sports injuries
Week 11: Oral presentation: exercise rehabilitation for sports injuries
Week 12: Revision and summary
Week 13: Final exam
(Individual course teachers may update the course syllabus as and whenever necessary.)

courses.subject: SPED
courses.title: Physiology of Human Performance
courses.description: The aim of this course is to provide the students with up-to-date and research-based information for understanding the physiological aspects of exercise. This course will examine the current concepts of energy metabolism and other physiological responses to exercise and training. Emphasis will be placed on the application of such knowledge upon the improvement of exercise performance and upon the promotion of exercise. The students will be provided with hands-on experience of conducting laboratory work which examines the metabolic responses to exercise.
courses.academic_group: Dept of Sports Sc & Phy Edu
courses.academic_org: Dept of Sports Sc & Phy Edu
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students will be able to:

• Understand the acute physiological changes that occur during exercise.

• Explain the metabolic responses involved in bioenergetics.

• Discuss the relationship between exercise intensity/duration and the physiological responses.

• Explain the influence of nutrition on human performance.

• Demonstrate the basic laboratory techniques on experimental testing.
courses.course_syllabus:
• Introduction to physiology and human performance

• Factors influencing exercise performance

• Bioenergetics and metabolism

• Energy metabolism and fatigue in working muscle

• Ergogenic aids and exercise performance

• Physiology of sedentary behavior

• Sport nutrition and exercise performance

• Thermoregulation and exercise performance

• Limitations to maximal oxygen uptake

• Seminar - Presentation of journal article

courses.subject: SPED
courses.title: Selected Topics in Sports Sociology
courses.description: This course is designed to enable the students to have a better understanding of sport sociology by going deep into the major sociological theories commonly used in sport sociology and to examine a number of key issues in sport sociology. Students will be taught to make use of the key concepts in the sociological theories learnt in the study of the selected topics in sport sociology, with a view to acquiring a better understanding of the relationship between sport and society. Students will also be asked to understand how sports development has been strongly influenced by the occurrence of some social processes, such as the political, economic and socio-cultural developments and the processes of globalization and commercialization. The issues of age and sport, gender and sport, and social classes and sport will also be examined.

courses.course_syllabus:
• Sociological theories in the study of sport in society: A revision

• The impact of governments’ involvement in sport on sports development

• The Impact of commercialization of sport on sports development

• The voluntary sector in sport and the development of social capital in sport

• Globalization and sport development

• The Impact of the hosting of mega sports events on sports development in the hosting countries or cities

• Gender difference and its impact on participation in sports and physical activity

• Age difference and Social Class difference and their impact on participation in sports and physical activity

• A sociological study of the development of sports policy and strategies in Hong Kong and in some other selected countries

• Tutorial: Is there a conflict between Elite Sport development and the promotion of Sport-for-All in Hong Kong?

courses.subject: SPED
courses.title: Introduction to Exercise and Sports Psychology
courses.description: This course is designed to cover a wide range of topics pertaining to motivation and subsequent performance in sports; to provide students with an understanding of some major theories derived from general psychology as the basis for examining their validity within the context of sport. Students will gain an understanding of the sport and exercise psychology principles as apply to performance and participation behaviours. They will also learn how to critically evaluate key theories and research findings within sport and exercise psychology, and their applications in real world contexts.

• Introduction and basic concepts

• Participants: personality, motivation

• Participants: arousal, stress and anxiety

• Sport environments: Competition and cooperation

• Group processes: Group cohesion

• Group processes: Leadership and communication

• Improving performance: Goal setting

• Health and well-being: Burnout and overtraining

• Psychological growth: Aggression in sport

• Psychological skills training

• Course overview and future directions

courses.subject: SPED
courses.title: Adapted Physical Education and Sports
courses.description: The term adapted physical education generally refers to school-based programs for students ages 3-21, the more global term adapted physical activity refers to programs across the life span, including post-school programs (i.e. adapted sport). This course is to enable students to better understand how physical education can be individualized to meet special and unique needs of learners. Through adopting an activity-based, problem-solving and inquiry approach, students are expected to be actively engaged in a broad spectrum of individual and collaborative tasks as well as other interactive modes of learning.
courses.academic_group: Dept of Sports Sc & Phy Edu
courses.academic_org: Dept of Sports Sc & Phy Edu
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students will be able to

• Identify the need of students of unique physical/social/emotional needs that individuals face in the physical setting of sport and physical education

• Select and adopt an appropriate teaching approach in order to accomplish specific teaching assignment

• Plan, implement and evaluate an effective special PE program that is relevant to the needs of school situation

• Attention Deficit & Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)

• Planning for Inclusion in P.E

• Individual Education Plan (IEP)

• Measurement & Assessment (practical)

• Mental Retardation & Down Syndrome

• Cerebral Palsy, Spinal Cord Disabilities

• Integrated Education – (a debate)

• Deafness and Visual Impairments

• Instructional Strategies for Adapted PE

• Guest Speaker and HK Athletes’ Sport Demonstration - Hong Kong Sports Association for the Mentally (HKSAM)

For educational benefits, a “turn-around” time of two to four weeks from the submission deadline is provided.

courses.subject: SPED
courses.title: Human Growth and Health Education
courses.description: This course provides students with an understanding of a number of concerns related to the growth, development, maturation in humans and the health at local and international level. Furthermore, the interaction of these factors with physical activity and exercise is examined. As development entails physiological, psychological and behavioral contexts, a multi-disciplinary approach is utilized in this course.

courses.description: Internship is one of the required courses for undergraduate students of the Department of Sports Science and Physical Education. It is a form of experiential learning, which provides opportunities for students to put the knowledge and skills they learned from the program into practice via engaging in a real-life career in the sports industry. Areas of sports industry attachment mainly focus on coaching, research, clinical attachment, health promotion and administration. Students are expected to observe rules, regulations and responsibility of a regular full-time employee of the industry they are attached to. The performance of student will be evaluated based upon a collection of performance of the internship and tutorial sessions, an internship report, and an evaluation report from the industry supervisor.

courses.description: Teaching Practice (TP) aims to provide opportunities to SSPE students practice their teaching skills through the implementation and verification of teaching theories into practice. With the supervisions and guidance of SSPE TP Supervisors, External TP Supervisors and Teaching Advisors, students can equip and prepare themselves as a competent physical education teacher in the future through the experiences acquired during teaching practice. Therefore, student-teachers would grasp this opportunity to experience and understand the real situation in teaching profession. Major students are required to take 8 units of Teaching Practice (TP). These units are spread over two years of study whereas students are placed in a variety of secondary schools to implement their teaching in authentic school environment and become acquainted with the organization, administration and discipline of secondary schools in Hong Kong. Students can design their physical education lessons by applying the pedagogical skills and teaching theories learnt in SPED3440 (pedagogy in secondary physical education) and other practical skill courses to the authentic teaching environment.

The content includes: Responsibilities of the Student-Teachers, School Details, Unit Plan, Lesson Plan, Management Strategies, Effective Demonstration, Class Observation, Teaching Practice Assessment Form, Student’s Self-evaluation Form, Teaching Practice Portfolio Marking Scheme.

courses.subject: SPED
courses.title: Physical Fitness Appraisal and Exercise Prescription
courses.description: This course aims to help students to acquire knowledge of the basic concepts of fitness testing and exercise prescription for general healthy population. Major health-related fitness components including cardiovascular fitness, muscular fitness, flexibility, body composition, and neuromuscular relaxation will be covered. Course format includes flipped classroom (e-learning), lectures, lab experience, and field trip (tbc). Through this course students will become proficient in administering the basic exercise tests typically used in field and corporate fitness setting, and be able to prescribe tailor-made exercise prescription for their clients. Students are expected to practice lab skills inside and outside class time. E-learning platform using flipped classroom and blackboard are mandatory.

courses.subject: SPED
courses.title: Education and Promotion of Exercise and Health
courses.description: This course will focus on the promotion of health, fitness and performance through the medium of exercise in the context of both the school and the wider community. Students will be made aware of the key concepts in this generic field of wellness and the potential of physical activity, exercise and the P.E. programme to facilitate its achievement. In addition, students will be enlightened in relation to the social context, lifestyle characteristics and health and fitness needs of their client, youth, families and communities in Hong Kong. Knowledge in such areas will enable them to design appropriate health skills programmes.
courses.academic_group: Dept of Sports Sc & Phy Edu
courses.academic_org: Dept of Sports Sc & Phy Edu
courses.learning_outcomes:
After taking this course, students will be able to:

• Understand the role of PE and exercise in promoting health, fitness and personal development in the community.

• Demonstrate an understanding of the relationship between health, fitness, lifestyle factors, exercise and PE programmes in Hong Kong society.

• Explain health behaviours with regard to a range of health habits, in terms of health-enhancement and health-compromisation.

• Understand the foci for health and exercise promotion intervention and the strategies associated with each level of intervention.

• Elucidate key aspects of Hong Kong popular culture and lifestyle and identify the lifestyle factors determining the physical activity participation attitudes and profiles of the Hong Kong family and youth.

• Identify the potential contribution of the Hong Kong health, fitness, sport, recreation and physical education service delivery system to lifelong health, fitness and personal development.

• Work as an effective agent of change relating to health risk and lifestyle behaviors and design a school and community-based health, fitness and physical activity programme for the promotion of health skills in a range of Hong Kong environments.
courses.course_syllabus:
• Health & Physical Activity: Concept and Health Outcomes

• Active Healthy Kids: Hong Kong Report Card

• Campus Walk: Understanding the Factors Influencing Physical Activity

• Neighborhood Built Environment and Physical Activity

• Exercise Promotion in Action

• Philosophical and Theoretical Foundations in Health Promotion

• Physical Activity for Children with Disabilities. Use of Internet and Health Promotion

• School Visit: Children with Special Needs

• Health Enhancing Physical Education: The CDC School Health Index for Health Promotion

• School Visit: Exercise Promotion

• Exercise and Health Promotion: Health-promoting School

courses.subject: SPED
courses.title: Human Kinematics and Kinetics
courses.description: The objective of this course is to provide students with knowledge and understanding regarding the kinematic and kinetic aspects of human movement. Four topics will be emphasized (1) biomechanical modeling of the human body; (2) principles and concepts of observing and analyzing the human performance; (3) biomechanical principles of optimal techniques in selected sports and movements; and (4) instrumentation and measurement in the biomechanics of human movement. Teaching and coaching examples will be provided in these topics.
courses.academic_group: Dept of Sports Sc & Phy Edu
courses.academic_org: Dept of Sports Sc & Phy Edu
courses.learning_outcomes:
At the completion of this course students will be able to:

• Understand the kinematic and kinetic methods used to analyze movement

• Understand how to quantify human movement and interpret results

• Understand the use of kinematic and kinetic analysis in the applied sport and clinical environments
courses.course_syllabus:
• Basic biomechanics

• Methods of sports biomechanics

• Observation and analyses of human performance

• Interpretation of collected data

• Application of biomechanics in coaching and teaching

courses.subject: SPED
courses.title: Psychological Aspects of Sports and Exercise
courses.description: To introduce students to theoretical and practical aspects of sports and exercise psychology. This course builds on the foundation of knowledge that was created in SPED3820 and covers psycho-social and developmental issues in the field.
courses.academic_group: Dept of Sports Sc & Phy Edu
courses.academic_org: Dept of Sports Sc & Phy Edu
courses.course_syllabus:
• Introduction to course and basic concepts

• Research process and ethical issues

• Exercise addiction and eating disorders

• Social facilitation and modeling

• Sports psychology in Hong Kong

• Moral and character development

• Psychological skills training

• Gender and cultural context

• Disability sports
courses.feedback_evaluation: Regular formative feedback from students will be collected during and after class through face-to-face/focus group meetings and other means where appropriate. Summative feedback will also be collected at the end of the course.
courses.recommended_readings:
• Gill, D. L., Williams, L., & Reifsteck, E. (2017). Psychological dynamics of sport and exercise. Champaign, IL: Human Kinetics.

• Raab, M., Wylleman, P., Seiler, R., Elbe,A-M., & Hatzigeorgiadis, A. (2016). Sport and exercise psychology research: From theory to practice. San Diego, CA: Academic Press.

• Weinberg, R. S., & Gould, D. (2015). Foundations of sport and exercise psychology. Champaign, IL: Human Kinetics.

• Van den Auweele, Y., Bakker, F., Biddle, S., Durand, M., & Seiler, R. (1999). Psychology for physical educators (Eds.). Champaign, IL: Human Kinetics.

Additional readings will be advised for some topics during the course. Selected reading materials will be provided when relevant.

courses.subject: SPED
courses.title: Research Project
courses.description: The Research Project is a compulsory course for final year undergraduate students of the Department of Sports Science and Physical Education. It aims to develop the student’s ability to conduct independent research in the area of physical education, exercise science and health. The development, undertaking and completion of the project is the culmination of the BEd/BSc learning experience and students must take and pass the course of Research Methods (SPED 3630) prior to enrolling to this course. It is intended to be a largely independent piece of work, which is aimed at combining and utilising the research skills and knowledge developed and gained from other relevant previous courses, and using these to complete a piece of original research within the student’s area of interest.
courses.academic_group: Dept of Sports Sc & Phy Edu
courses.academic_org: Dept of Sports Sc & Phy Edu
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, it is expected that each student will be able to:

• Plan and execute a piece of research work in a systematic way,

• Collect, analyse, interpret, and critically examine the evidence during the entire research process,

• Arrange logically and express clearly the results of an investigation,

• Display knowledge of a specific aspect of exercise science and health,

• Demonstrate the application of knowledge and method to an investigation of a specific area in the field,

• Identify an issue to which solutions and/or recommendations can be addressed; and produce a written report which sets out clearly the aims, context, content and outcome of an investigation, and

• Integrate the skills and knowledge which have been taught in the degree programme with specific application to a topic to produce a well-argued report.
courses.course_syllabus: There are no lectures and set week-to-week tasks in this course. Rather, required tasks to be performed are discussed between student and supervisor.
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are welcome to express feedback on course contents and learning experience via e-mail to the course instructors anytime during the course.
